conclusion: Analyze the graph of acceleration versus time to determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point.
The graph shows acceleration as a function of time; the particle starts from rest with initial velocity zero.
Velocity is the integral of acceleration with respect to time.
From t=0 to t=t0, acceleration increases linearly from 0 to a0; from t=t0 to t=2t0, it decreases linearly from a0 to -a0.
Calculate velocity for 0 ≤ t ≤ t0: v(t) = (a0 t^2) / (2t0). At t = t0, v(t0) = (a0 t0) / 2.
Calculate velocity for t0 ≤ t ≤ 2t0: v(t) = a0 t - (a0 / t0) (t - t0)^2 - (a0 t0) / 2.
Position is the integral of velocity with respect to time.
Calculate position for 0 ≤ t ≤ t0: x(t) = (a0 t^3) / (6t0). At t = t0, x(t0) = (a0 t0^2) / 6.
Calculate position for t0 ≤ t ≤ 2t0: x(t) = (a0 t0^2) / 6 + (a0 t^2) / 2 - (a0 / 3t0) (t - t0)^3 - (a0 t0 / 2) t.
The particle is farthest from the starting point when velocity v(t) is zero.
Set v(t) = 0 and solve for t to find when the particle is farthest.
The particle is farthest from the starting point at t = (3t0) / 2.
